posts.cooked:
Hello, I’m trying to link my phone to the desktop app. However, I apparently need to scan a QR code in order to do so. This presents a problem as my phone’s camera does not work. I’ve seen similar posts with no clear answer as to how to link the two.

  1. This does appear to be a recurring problem as I’ve seen many others online are having the same problem. Will a workaround be officially added to the signal app?
  2. How would I link my phone to the desktop app now?

link_counts.title: QR Code scan with broken lense

posts.cooked:
tsobey:

Will a workaround be officially added to the signal app?

If you want an official answer, I cannot help you there, the signal foundation folks do not reveal what is being worked on internally, until it is deemed ready for release. (Edit: see Link devices manually without QR · Issue #5153 · signalapp/Signal-Android · GitHub by Moxie in early 2017… this is “on the roadmap” but no timeline given.) If you want my guesstimate-hunch, it seems unlikely this will happen soon, because it is difficult to keep messages private without having a strong security-linkage between the slave-devices and the master-device. Moreover, using the optional anti-MitM verification works using QR codes via signal4smartphone’s built-in QR-scanner, as well. Like using signal4desktop, verifying safety-nums is non-mandatory / optional, partly because it requires hardware that does not always exist/work on the endpoint-device. Not everybody owns a laptop, and not everybody has a functional phone-cam.

Maybe it would make sense, that if clicked eight times, the rendered QR-code imagefile on signal4desktop would display an all-numeric-version, and if tapped eight times, the QR-scanner over on signal4android would reveal a hidden text-area where the vNumpad could be used to tap in the 100-digit-linkage-string?

At present, by design there is always exactly one single smartphone-device associated with a given signal-num backed by a matching underlying telco-num, and up to five (or six?) slave-devices running signal4desktop on 64-bit x86-based windows/linuxDEB/osx systems like a laptop or PC are allowed. Some functionality is only available in the master-smartphone-device: addressbook-integration, createGroup / LeaveGroup / etc, full text search, cryptocalls/SMS/MMS, and various other shortcomings of slave-devices.

tsobey:

appear to be a recurring problem

One of the biggest shortcomings is, methinks, the level of UX complexity/prereqs:

  • install signal4smartphone first from the internet, it is required by signal4desktop
  • register with a valid telco-num beforehand, to get into the slave-linkage-submenu
  • install signal4desktop onto a supported OS and CPU, from the internet
  • launch signal4desktop to display the linkage-QR-code onto the laptop-screen
  • launch signal4smartphone, and use the linked device menu to scan the laptop’s QR from within signal4smartphone’s built-in scanner-component via phone-cam

If there is a failure at any stage, sometimes there are workaround and sometimes there are not workarounds.

tsobey:

my phone’s camera does not work

In your particular situation, the problem is that you have a phone-cam which does not work. Can you be more specific here? Which problem-class?

typical problem-classes + workarounds: wrong app, bad focus, sw bug
  1. phone-cam functions, scans the QR code okay: but signal4desktop never notices?
  2. phone-cam functions, takes photos okay: but never manages to focus the QR code?
  3. phone-cam unrecognized by signal4smartphone: you can take photos from the stock camera-app, but cannot take photos nor scan QR within signal4smartphone?
  4. phone-cam is physically busted: scratched lens or dead imager-chip or similar

Depending on what the exact does-not-work-right situation is that you are in, the workarounds are basically to

  1. make SURE you are using signal4smartphone’s built-in QR code scanner, NOT the phone’s stock camera-app nor barcode-app.
  2. use a different display or a different distance or a printed copy or a zoomed/shrunken version of the QR code you are trying to scan to overcome failure-to-focus scanner-issues.
  3. upload a debuglog from signal4smartphone if it won’t even OPEN the phone-cam at all because presumably there is a software problem related to the signalapp codebase or to the OS/ROM used on your handset.
  4. various workarounds to try and get temporary access to a physically-functional digicam of some sort so that you can let signal4smartphone actually scan the QR code signal4desktop is displaying.

For the generic situation#4 where your phone-cam is unusable, for whatever specific reason, there are a few unofficial DIY ways that you can bypass the hurdle:

generic ways: upgrade phone, temp phone-switch, usb-webcam, hand-compile

  • 4A. upgrade to a handset with a working phone-cam (i.e. permanently)

  • 4B. if you are on signal4android, you can also temporarily cross-grade to another android handset with a working phone-cam, and then revert back to your main handset with the non-working phone-cam, as follows:

    • acquire a trustworthy secondaryPhone handset, which does NOT have signal4smartphone on it, and which DOES have a working phone-cam
    • on your mainPhone create an encrypted-backup-blob#1,
    • write down the 30-digit decrypt-passphrase#1
    • on your secondaryPhone install signal4android (but don’t register)
    • file-copy the backup-blob#1 from mainPhone over to secondaryPhone
    • making sure you are prompted to restore from the backup-blob#1 during the effort, register your +1-111-111-1111 signal-num on secondaryPhone
    • you now have your signal-identity on secondaryPhone
    • install signal4desktop, launch it, scan the QR code via secondaryPhone
    • wait an hour or so to make sure signal4desktop is FULLY working/sync’d
    • send some test-messages from signal4desktop to a couple contacts
    • reverse the process: on your secondaryPhone, create backup-blob#2
    • write down the 30-digit decrypt-passphrase#2
    • on your mainPhone, you will (still) have signal4android installed
    • file-copy the backup-blob#2 from secondaryPhone over to mainPhone
    • making sure you are prompted to restore from the backup-blob#2 during the effort, register your +1-111-111-1111 signal-num on mainPhone again
    • you now have your signal-identity back on mainPhone
    • securely delete all cache/appData/backupBlobs/etc from secondaryPhone
    • don’t attempt this with a handset you do not TRUST to be malware-free
    • the backup-blobs ARE needed… that is how you retain the linked-device!
    • all told this is a fairly slow hurry-up-and-wait process, needs a few hours

  • 4C. Investigate whether you can plug a usb-webcam into your handset with the busted or non-working-for-whatever-reason phone-cam, and get signalapp to take photos via the little camera-icon (or the linked-device QR-scanner menu).

    • most usb-webcams are made for windows/intel machines, you may have to try more than one webcam before you can get it to work on android/linux https://www.google.com/search?q=android+usb+webcam (or, ios)
    • most usb-webcams are electrically-compatible with the charger-port on smartphone handsets, via a usb-dongle to alter the connector shape/size
    • not all webcams will support the Android Camera2 API signal4android uses
    • it might be impossible to get signal4android to use the “3rd cam” (via usb)
    • however, worth trying, as you may have a usb webcam you can use/borrow

  • 4D. If you, or someone you know well enough to trust them with your cryptographic keys, have the skills to hand-compile signal4android, and sideload, this can be a workaround of sorts. You could make some DIY modifications to accept a PNG file containing the QR-code rather than using Camera2 API to scannerize it, for example? Various other code-changes could also be made.

    • however, there is a major downside: it is not easy to start using a hand-compiled version of signal4android, there is a lot of setup required
    • worse, unless you WANT to keep using a hand-compiled version (i.e. regularly downloading the source and re-compiling and re-sideloading) you will have trouble switching back to the non-modified official signal4android!
    • essentially, to only temporarily use an altered APK that you hand-compiled, just for linking a slave-device, you will need to go through the process up above related to temporarily using the phone-cam of secondaryPhone: backup-blob#3 from your official APK, restore it into your hand-compiled APK with the QR-bypass alterations, link the slave-laptop, backup-blob#4 from your hand-compiled APK, restore it into your official APK … which is a lot of work!
    • however, if you are really only able to get access to ONE handset (with non-working phone-cam for whatever reason), and ONE laptop or PC (where you can install AndroidStudio and such to hand-compile), this could work.
    • rather than software-only 4D, most people will be better off looking into hardware workarounds like 4A handset upgrade, 4B temporary handset-switcheroo, 4C temporary usb-webcam use.
tsobey:

no clear answer as to how to link the two

Hopefully the above workarounds give you a taste of what is commonly recommended when the phone-cam is refusing to let you link signal4desktop via QR.

p.s. However, there is another way to look at the problem: what is the purpose you are installing signal4desktop to solve, what is the motive? Sometimes you don’t need signal4desktop proper, to get some of the advantages people want from it.

wilder tricks: ext keyb, ext display, remote-ctrl, android VM, laptop-only

  • In particular, if you want a larger hardware-keyboard, you CAN control your signal4smartphone handset via bluetooth-keyb, or via usb-dongle-adapter which allows you to plug in a regular usb-keyb from a PC, into your smartphone.

  • If you mostly want a larger display, there are several kinds of workaround (depending on your exact handset-model and OS version) where you can try to Miracast or HDMI-out or otherwise get your smartphone to put pixels onto an external screen distinct from the handset-touchscreen. Scan barcode when opening Signal - #4 by 5_c_d and Run Signal Desktop in portable mode - #6 by 5_c_d have more details.

  • There are also various sorts of remote-control-my-phone type software solutions, where you install a remote-controller-application onto your laptop, and then install a remote-controllee-app onto your smartphone, which allows you to “see your phone in a laptop-window” kind of thing. This is not as good as signal4desktop which is NOT reverse-tethered, but people used to the whatsapp4web approach where the smartphone must be on and connected and internet-enabled and charged, might be satisfied with this kind of a workaround.

  • If you really want to have SOME kind of signalapp on your laptop, and you have a secondary telco-num available (landline or work-phone or twilio voip or google-voice or various gratis service-providers in certain situations), one thing you can do is to install a virtual-machine onto your laptop, such as the AndroidEmulator thing that comes with AndroidStudio, hand-compile signal4android, install it into the VM on your laptop, register with a secondary phone-num, and then use that as your signalapp-on-a-laptop solution?

  • You can go further, and install signal4android into a VM on your laptop, then utilizing an external usb-webcam, also install signal4desktop on that same laptop, and take a picture of your own laptop-screen to link the signal4android to the signal4desktop slave! This allows you to utilize signal without ever getting a physical smartphone-handset at all, and requires just one laptop and a bit of fiddling around to get it working. There is a downside that you cannot usually fit your laptop in your bluejeans pocket, and cannot usually hold your laptop to your head during a cryptocall in the signal4android VM, but some folks won’t mind.

  • At least one person, uses the following trick: install unofficial AsamK/signal-cli fork onto laptop as a master-device, install unofficial Trolldemorted/signal-android fork which has been modified to support slave-device operation (and link it to cli-master), install official signal4desktop and also link it to cli-master. Link devices manually without QR · Issue #5153 · signalapp/Signal-Android · GitHub …however note that this comment is from 2017 when signal4chromeApp was still around, it is now fully unsupported and you should instead use the modern signal4desktop nowadays (presumably it can still link to a cli-master but the steps will obviously differ from the signal4chromeApp steps that @Trolldemorted gives)

posts.name: Thebundok
posts.cooked:
Just want to throw my hat in the ring on this request (I realize I’m resurrecting a 6 year old thread).

In my case, I work in a secured facility where we are not allowed to bring phones in. I can install Signal to my device, but I can’t register it.

For other 2FA requirements (e.g. logging in to Gmail) all I have to do is go back out to my phone and acknowledge a keyword phrase or image provided by the desktop app. I’m not sure why this method wouldn’t be considered as a viable option.

thebundok:

In my case, I work in a secured facility where we are not allowed to bring phones in. I can install Signal to my device, but I can’t register it.

if i would be running secure organization, i wouldn’t allow ordinary smartphones either. i might allow un-googled androids, even though i don’t totally like android even as un-googled. ios would be totally out.

thebundok:

For other 2FA requirements (e.g. logging in to Gmail) all I have to do is go back out to my phone and acknowledge a keyword phrase or image provided by the desktop app. I’m not sure why this method wouldn’t be considered as a viable option.

maybe this should be feature request or something. i think linking should be possible without camera and qr-codes.

not necessarily solution in your case, but look at it.

https://github.com/AsamK/signal-cli
